title: Some Antibiotic Stagnation
summary:
Key ideas
- A graph about using antibiotics to measure the rate of scientific progress is circulating the internet.
- The graph is inaccurate: several listed drugs are not antibiotics, while important antibiotics are left out.
- Antibiotic discovery has declined but is not as severe as the graph suggests.
- Antibiotic discovery has become more complex, expensive, and time-consuming over time; the regulatory pathway to antibiotic approval is also poor.

Key learnings
- Antibiotic discovery has declined, but not as much as the inaccurate graph suggests.
- Antibiotic discovery has become more complex, expensive, and time-consuming over time, with poor regulatory pathways to approval.

Key questions
- What are the three principal causes of the antibiotic market failure?
- How does the FDA approve antibacterials, and why is it problematic?
- What is the cause of the decline in antibiotic discovery in addition to the scientific complexity, economic incentives, and regulatory pathway issues?
